direction.raw_text: She senses Bock watching her, turns, smiles. She's a very beautiful girl. She returns to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She returns the receiver to its cradle. When she looks up again, Bock is no longer there. She returns the flight tickets to her purse, snaps it shut, stands and moves to the doorway, enters a step into...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in background on phone) ...Drummond, first name, Barbara. I'll pay cash...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) No, you're to pick up my father, Drummond, Edward, at the Manhattan Medical Center, Holly Pavilion, Room Eight-O-Six. It's a stretcher case. I presume you provide the stretcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's to be taken to American Airlines, Yes... No... Kennedy Airport, Flight Seven-Two-Nine to Yuma, Arizona. I'll accompany the patient... Yes, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bock, back at his desk, looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock drains his glass and pours her a hefty shot of bourbon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara throws back her head and roars with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pauses, her story over. Throughout, Bock has been trying to keep his glowering eye on the desktop. During her long narrative, he once seized the bottle and took a swig. Mostly he is finding the experience murkily sensual. His glance keeps darting out from under his brows to surreptitiously look at the beautiful long tanned legs; or, when she bends for the drink she set on the floor, to peer down the flapping open scalloped neck of her dress; she is bra-less. She, on the other hand, has been crossing and uncrossing her legs, bending, stretching, so that her short dress has ridden up almost to her waist and is saved from utter exhibitionism only by the darkness of the shadows. She seems unaffected by Bock's voyeuristic interest in her, but she is surely not unaware of it. It is hard to believe she is not courting his attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock looks up, and they suddenly find their eyes locked. The dark, dense air in the room fairly steams with incipient sexuality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a crash of his fist on the desktop, Bock stands; he is in a drunken rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He suspects he is going to cry and turns quickly away. He sits heavily and fights his tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are both suddenly conscious of a third presence in the room. They look to the door where Mr. Blacktree, fully clothed again and carrying his coat, is standing in the doorway. Barbara uncrosses her long legs and stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara regards his hunched form and, murmuring in Apache, she exits, closing the door. In the subsequent hush, thunder RUMBLES and CRASHES. Wind sweeps the rain against the window panes. The sounds go unheeded by Bock, still as marble. Slowly, he raises his head and sighs and then fishes about in his jacket pockets to bring out the bottle of potassium and syringe. He takes off his jacket, rolling up his shirtsleeve, poking about for the vein. He removes his trouser belt, which he ties tightly about his upper arm for a tourniquet. Now, he tears the wrapping of the syringe and fits the needle to it. Fiddling about in the pockets of his jacket, he finally finds a crumpled pack of cigarettes. He lights one and returns to the business of killing himself, puffing expressionlessly as he does. Thunder RUMBLES and rain SLASHES. He carefully draws just the right amount of potassium from the bottle to the syringe, peering at the procedure against the light of his desk lamp. He sets the cigarette on the ashtray, switches the hypodermic to his right hand, holds his left arm rigidly out under the light of the lamp...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns slowly to the doorway, his bare left arm still rigidly extended, the belt dangling, the hypodermic clenched in his other hand. Barbara is perfectly framed in the doorway. He stares at her, slowly suffusing with the numb, blind, total rage of the aborted suicide. The thunder CRASHES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She approaches the desk affably, turns the potassium around to read the label.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock's rage erupts. He crashes the hypodermic syringe down, shattering it. The potassium puddles on the wood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves around the desk, a shambling bear of a man, a leather belt dangling dementedly from his arm, tears coursing down his cheeks. He advances on her in a stuperous shuffle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She regards his lumbering approach with a faint, grotesquely sensual smile. He reaches with his naked left arm to the neck of her dress and, with one savage wrench, rips her stark naked, sobbing through hysterical tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is on her, crushing her down into the shadows of the couch, ravenous at her neck and shoulders in a brutish assault, sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throughout the scene, CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN through the flesh and fury to an INTENSE TWO-SHOT of this terrified act of love. Then slowly over Bock's plunging shoulder to the woman's face. She gasps at the moment of penetration, then her lovely face slowly shapes into smiling serenity. Bock sobs; even in the shadows we can see the path of the tears on his cheek.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You believe in witchcraft, Miss Drummond?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I believe in everything, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from the door suddenly) My father, you should know, was a very successful doctor in Boston, a member of the Harvard Medical Faculty. He was a widower, and I was his only child. He was not an especially religious man, a sober Methodist. One evening, seven years ago, he attended a Pentecostal meeting in the commons rooms at Harvard and suddenly found himself speaking in tongues. (she takes her drink and crosses to the sofa) That is to say, he suddenly sank to his knees at the back of the room and began to talk fluently in a language which no one had ever heard before. This sort of thing happens frequently at Pentecostal meetings, and they began to happen regularly to my father. (she sits) It was not unusual to walk into our home and find my father sitting in his office, utterly serene and happily speaking to the air in this strange foreign tongue. I was, at that time twenty years old and having my obligatory affair with a minority group, in my case a Hopi Indian, a post-graduate fellow at Harvard doing his doctorate in the aboriginal languages of the Southwest. One day, I brought the Indian boy home just as my father was sinking to his knees in the entrance foyer in one of his trances. The Indian wheeled in his tracks and said, "Well, I'll be a sonofabitch." You see, my father was speaking an Apache dialect, an obscure dialect at that, spoken only by a ragged band of unreconstructed Indians who had rejected the reservation and were living in total isolation in the Sierra Madre Mountains of northern Mexico. Well! What do you say to that, Dr. Bock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who has been staring at her as if she were insane) What the hell am I supposed to say to that, Miss Drummond?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sitting here boozing and, all of a sudden, you start telling me some demented story about your father's religious conversion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, you miss the point, Doctor. Not my father's conversion -- mine. You see, I had been hitting the acid pretty regularly at that time. I had achieved a few minor sensory deformities, some suicidal despairs, but nothing as wild as fluency in an obscure Apache dialect. I mean, like wow, man! I mean, here was living afflatus right before my eyes! Within a week, my father had closed his Beacon Hill practice and set out to start a mission in the Mexican mountains. And I turned in my S.D.S. card and my crash helmet and followed him. It was a disaster, at least for me. My father had received the revelation, not I. He stood gaunt on a mountain slope and preached the apocalypse to solemnly amused Indians. I masturbated a great deal. We lived in a grass wickiup and ate raw rabbit and crushed pinon nuts. It was hideous. Within two months, I was back in Boston, a hollow shell and dizzy with dengue, disenchanted with everything. I turned to austerity, combed my hair tight and entered nursing school. I became haggard, driven and had shamelessly incestuous dreams about my father. I took up with some of the senior staff at the hospital. One of them, a portly psychiatrist, explained I was generated by an unresolved lust for my father. I apparently cracked up. One day, they found me walking to work naked and screaming obscenities. There was talk of institutionalizing me, so I packed a bag and went back to my father in the Sierra Madre Mountains. I've been there ever since. That's three years. My father is, of course, mad as a hatter. I watch over him and have been curiously content. You see, Doctor, I believe in everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now what was that all about, Miss Drummond?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I was obvious as hell. I'm trying to tell you I have a thing for middle-aged men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I admire your candor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been admiring a lot more than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks down again) You're wasting your time. I've been impotent for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rubbish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lurches about) What the hell's wrong with being impotent? My God, you kids are more hung up on sex than the Victorians! I've got a son, twenty-three. I threw him out of the house last year. Pietistic little humbug. He preached universal love and despised everyone. He had a blanket contempt for the middle class, even its decencies. He detested my mother because she had petit bourgeois pride in her son the doctor. I cannot tell you how brutishly he ignored that rather good old lady. When she died, he didn't even come to the funeral. He thought the chapel service an hypocrisy. His generation didn't live with lies, he told me. "Everybody lives with lies," I said. I grabbed him by his poncho, dragged him the full length of our seven-room despicably affluent middle-class apartment and flung him out. I haven't seen him since. But do you know what he said to me as he stood there on that landing on the verge of tears. He shrieked at me: "You old fink! You can't even get it up anymore!" That was it, you see. That was his real revolution. It wasn't racism and the oppressed poor and the war in Vietnam. The ultimate American societal sickness was a limp dingus. Hah! (he lurches about, laughing rustily) My God, if there is a despised and misunderstood minority in this country, it's us poor impotent bastards. Well, I'm impotent and proud of it! Impotence is beautiful, baby! (he raises a militant fist) Power to the Impotent! Right on, baby!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Right on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stares drunkenly at her) When I say impotent, I don't mean merely limp. Disagreeable as it may be for a woman, a man may sometimes lust for other things, something less transient than an erection, some sense of permanent worth. That's what medicine was for me, my reason for being. When I was thirty-four, Miss Drummond, I presented a paper before the annual convention of the Society of Clinical Investigation that pioneered the whole goddam field of immunology. A breakthrough! I'm in all the textbooks. I happen to be an eminent man, Miss Drummond. And you want to know something, Miss Drummond? I don't give a goddam. When I say I'm impotent, I mean I've lost even my desire for work, which is a hell of a lot more primal a passion than sex. I've lost my raison d'etre, my purpose, the only thing I ever truly loved. It's all rubbish anyway. Transplants, antibodies, we manufacture genes, we can produce birth ectogenetically, we can practically clone people like carrots, and half the kids in this ghetto haven't even been inoculated for polio! We have assembled the most enormous medical establishment ever conceived, and people are sicker than ever! We cure nothing! We heal nothing! The whole goddam wretched world is strangulating in front of our eyes! That's what I mean when I say impotent! You don't know what the hell I'm talking about, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm tired, I'm terribly tired, Miss Drummond. And I hurt, and I've got nothing going for me anymore. Can you understand that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then can you understand that the only admissable matter left is death?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds to me like a familiar case of morbid menopause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Christ.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's hard for me to take your despair very seriously, Doctor. You obviously enjoy it so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, bugger off. That's all I need now, clinical insights. Some cockamamie twenty-five-year-old...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...acidhead's going to reassure me about menopause now. Look, I'd like to be alone, so why don't you beat it? Close the door and turn off the lights on your way out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crossing to the door) Mr. Blacktree disapproves of my miniskirt, but it was the only thing I had to come to the city with. Back at the tribe, I wear ankle-length buckskin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swell. Just close the door and turn off the lights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) What're you shooting, Doc?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely gets the words out) Leave me alone...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Potassium. You take enough of this stuff, it'll kill you, Doc. (moves toward the couch) It occurred to me that I might have read you wrong, that you really were suicidal. So I came back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hysterical rage) Who the hell asked you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the hell asked you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone! Why the hell don't you leave me alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you let me do it? Who the hell asked you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 4:00 A.M. The quiet, black streets glisten wetly in the puddles of lamplight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The night shift is finishing up. THERESA CAMPANELLA, R.N., a high-strung girl in her early twenties, stands at a water tap holding a glass and popping some pills in her mouth. To the room:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Campanella comes out of the Dialysis room, puts on her coat and walks to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Campanella moves down the empty corridor. All the doors are closed now; only the overhead light in the background of the corridor glows weakly. Campanella puts a cigarette in her mouth, pauses to look for matches; she hasn't any. Scowling with annoyance, she continues to the lobby and stops by a partially visible white-jacketed figure reading a newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes the matches, lights her cigarette, inhaling deeply, when he suddenly sandbags her from behind. She goes down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have a match, Doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAYBREAK, WEDNESDAY Covered by Bock's overcoat, Barbara tosses and turns on the couch in a small nightmare. Through the windows comes the first gray wash of dawn. FULL SHOT of Barbara, awake and up on one elbow on the verge of a scream. She looks around the room. It is dark, empty, silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara looking through the door to the secretarial office. It is likewise dark, but suddenly the lights go on and, a moment later, Bock enters. He holds a container of coffee in each hand and has something white draped over his forearm. From under Bock's bulky coat, Barbara watches him lumber to his desk, where he sets the containers of coffee down. He drops the whitish garment over the back of a chair and then sits. He hoists a bulging folder of correspondence from his filing tray and hunches to work, reading. After a moment, he regards the silent figure on the couch across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises, picks up the second container and white dress from the chair. She reaches out an arm for the coffee. Bock holds up -- a nurse's uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has perched on the edge of the couch, and she rests her cheek against the long, bent curve of his back, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to look at her, smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sips her coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stare at each other, she in terror, he with affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sets her coffee down on the couch and decides to wear Bock's overcoat rather than use it as a cover. She searches for the sleeves. Bock assists her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By now she's standing, the overcoat reaching her toes. She looks down at Bock perched on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara reaches for her coffee, sips, moves around in her tent of a coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This last in reference to Barbara crossing to the secretaries' office, zippering her uniform.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't be awake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swiped this for you out of the nurses' locker room. I'll make good on your dress. I'm afraid it's torn beyond repair. Buy yourself a new one or, if you like, give me your size and I'll send it on to you. But I want to talk to you about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk to me about what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About your father. You really shouldn't move him in his condition. I just had a look at his chart. There's no reason to presume brain damage. You know as well as I you can't predict anything in these instances. He could pull out of that coma at any time. I think you should let him stay here. I'll personally look after him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this your way of saying you'd like me to stay in town a few more days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that would be nice, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you say, Miss Drummond?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I expect you can call me Barbara, considering you ravished me three times last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three times?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, look at him, pretending he didn't count. You were as puffed up as a toad about it. Punched a couple of holes in your crusade for universal impotence, didn't it? I think we're on a first name basis by now. I'll call you Herb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's give your father a week, Barbara, what do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a frown darkens her face) No, I don't want my father in this hospital. I had a dream about this hospital. (some of the terror shows on her face) I dreamt this enormous starched white tile building suddenly erupted like a volcano, and all the patients, doctors, nurses, attendants, orderlies, the whole line staff, the food service people, the aged, the lame -- and you right in the middle -- were stampeding in one hideous screaming suicidal mass into the sea. (she stares at him wide-eyed, reliving the dream) I'm taking my father out of here -- and as quickly as I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a real fruitcake, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let me put it this way. I love you. I fancied you from the first moment you came lumbering down that hallway upstairs. I said to Mr. Blacktree, "Who's that hulking bear of a man?" The Apaches are reverential about bears. They won't eat bear meat; they never skin bears. Bear is thought of as both benign and evil, but very strong power. Men with bear power are highly respected and are frequently said to be great healers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said to Mr. Blacktree, "That man gets his power from the bear."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swell. Now, look, do you have a hotel, some sort of accommodations where you can stay for a week or so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, let me put it this way, Herb. My father and I accept the implacability of death. If he dies, he dies, but I'm taking him out of here and back to Mexico about one o'clock this afternoon. I want you to come with us, because I love you and want children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid Mexico sounds a little too remote for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could use you down there, you know. There's a curiously high incidence of T.B. And you'd be a doctor again, Herb. You'd be necessary again. If you love me, I don't see what other choice you have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, if I love you? I raped you in a suicidal rage. How did we get to love and children all of a sudden?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, for heaven's sake, Herb, I ought to know if a man loves me or not. You must have told me half a hundred times last night you loved me. You murmured it, shouted it; one time, you opened the window and bellowed it out into the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think those were more expressions of gratitude than love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gratitude for what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, my God, for resurrecting feelings of life in me I thought dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, my God, what do you think love is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, I love you, and you love me. I'm not about to argue with so relentless a romantic. Well, then, since we have this great passion going for us, I don't see why you won't stay on here in New York for a week or ten days...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's up to ten days now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As long as it takes for your father's condition to improve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I've had these prophetic dreams for seven nights. Seven is a sinister number. The meaning of these dreams is very clear, seven times as clear. I am to get my father and you out of this hospital before we are all destroyed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (throws up his hands) You're certifiable! My God, half the time you're a perfectly intelligent young woman, and then suddenly you turn into a goddam cabalist who believes in dreams, witchcraft and bear power! And I don't like the way you dismiss my whole life as unnecessary. I do a lot of healing right here in Manhattan. I don't have to go to Mexico for it. I also teach. I send out eighty doctors a year into the world, sometimes inspirited, at least competent. I've built up one of the best damned departments of medicine in the world. We've got a hell of a heart unit here and a hell of a kidney group. A lot of people come into this hospital in big trouble, Miss Drummond, and go out better for the experience. So don't tell me how unnecessary I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who's been slipping into the nurse's uniform) Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how come, eight hours ago, you were trying to kill yourself with an overdose of potassium?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (gathering her coat and purse) My hotel. I have to check out. Mr. Blacktree doesn't speak any English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slips into her coat and exits, as Bock looks after her thoughtfully, then turns back to his own office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (from the connecting doorway) Well, you're coming back, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. I have to settle the bill here and pack my father. And I think you need a few hours alone to make your decisions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What decisions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a very tired and very damaged man. You've had a hideous marriage and I assume a few tacky affairs along the way. You're understandably reluctant to get involved again. And, on top of that, here I am with the preposterous idea you throw everything up and go off with me to some barren mountains of Mexico. It sounds utterly mad, I know. On the other hand, you obviously find this world as desolate as I do. You did try to kill yourself last night. So that's it, Herb. Either me and the mountains or the bottle of potassium. I'll be back in an hour or so. I'll be in my father's room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He shuffles around distractedly, not knowing how to articulate the exuberance he feels. Suddenly, he opens the window, leans out and bellows to the empty air.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right. I love you! (softly) My God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: ON THIS LOCATION, THE NEW YORK MEDICAL UNIVERSITY CENTER WILL BUILD A DRUG REHABILITATION COMMUNITY CENTER, TO BE COMPLETED IN 1973

direction.raw_text: . DAWN A construction sign fills the screen. It reads ON THIS LOCATION, THE NEW YORK MEDICAL UNIVERSITY CENTER WILL BUILD A DRUG REHABILITATION COMMUNITY CENTER, TO BE COMPLETED IN 1973. E.F. SCHLAGER & CO., CONTRACTORS. Suddenly, the sign comes crashing down into CAMERA. It has been wrenched off the wooden fence protecting the row of tenements and brownstones being demolished. About a dozen young and loud militants have torn it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S to show the row of houses behind the fence, two of which have already been reduced to rubble; the others have been boarded up. The demolition generators and cranes are parked silently along the curb. In the dark of 5:00 A.M., three black families, carrying children, and children carrying household effects, mattresses, pots, pans, bags of groceries, etc., are repossessing the condemned buildings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY, 10:00 A.M. Strong sun overhead. The street has been roped off, and police are all over the place. A sparse crowd of a hundred or so throng the sidestreets off First Avenue. Signs read, "People Si, Doctors No." A Channel 11 mobile news crew, newspaper photographers, and a radio newscaster are recording the situation with desultory interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands in the middle of the cordoned street, bullhorning the occupiers of the condemned brownstones, who can be seen through the broken windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A piece of brick arches down from the roof of a building and cracks the street a few feet from the Captain.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I repeat. I'm asking you to come out peacefully. These buildings are condemned and unfit for habitation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs, tries again) You people are possessing this building illegally and in violation of the law. I'm asking you to come out peacefully...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A small press conference is going on in a corner of the lobby. Reporters cluster, and TV cameras surround the Press Representative of the Hospital, a young woman in her thirties named EVELYN BASSEY, who is trying to read a statement, squinting under her mod glasses at the blaze of lights set up by the camera crews.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BASSEY (reading) ...complete sympathy with the tenants. So the hospital has assumed the responsibility of finding 400 housing units in good buildings. The hospital wishes to point out that this particular row of buildings on First Avenue was condemned by the City before the hospital acquired ownership, and even then, only after responsible leaders in the community had approved the building of our new drug rehabilitation center.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (explodes on the phone) Goddammit, Barry, I've got a dozen community leaders waiting for me in the library! We've been trying to work out some kind of negotiable formula for two years! And with no help from you people in the Urban Affairs Division, I might add!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WELBECK appears in the doorway. He's in his fifties, gray, distinguished and very tanned with terribly, terribly kindly old country doctor eyes. He wears a camel hair topcoat. He smiles benignly and twinkles at Sundstrom from one of the leather chairs across the desk from the Director.

A large blackboard faces the Supervisor's Office with the day's schedule of operations neatly chalked in. It is full. A middle-aged surgeon, still in his overcoat, is studying the schedule. (dials) It gives you a variety of deferral devices, profit-sharing for example. Let's say you pick yourself an October 31-fiscal. You declare a bonus payable in '71. An accrued item payable to a principle share-holder must be paid within two and half months after the close of the year to get the deduction in the prior year. But your corporation doesn't pay that tax, because we've eliminated the taxable income with the bonus. With two taxable entities, you can bury a hell of a lot of expenses... (on phone) Hello, this is Welbeck, any messages?... Well, I'm at the hospital. I have to cut open some guy in a couple of minutes. I'll try to make it as fast as I can. How urgent did he say it was?... Well, Dr. Hogan made those arrangements with the underwriters. The Registration Statement was filed with the S.E.C. well over a year ago... If he calls again, have me paged here. (hangs up, turns back to the attentive young doctors to conduct his class in medical finance while changing into surgical scrub) The really big money is in health leasing, of course. Dr. Hogan, the eminent orthopedic surgeon, and I incorporated a leasing company and went public last year. I hold a controlling interest in a number of proprietary hospitals, nursing homes and rest farms, and I've been leasing hospital equipment to my own hospitals at excessive rates. Why, you ask, am I draining my own hospitals? Well, my hospitals are taxed at 48 percent, and I'm giving my leasing company a hell of a price-earnings ratio, which'll balloon the market value of the stock. I hold three hundred thousand shares of that stock, lettered of course, but in a year, I'll dump those shares at a capital gain and walk off with a bundle...

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why you even hesitate. What's holding you here? Is it your wife?

dialogue.raw_text: No, that's all over. I suppose if I'm married to anything, it's this hospital. It's been my whole life. I just can't walk out on it as if it never mattered. I'm middle-class. Among us middle-class, love doesn't triumph over all. Responsibility does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herb, don't ask me to stay here with you, because I love you, and I will. And we'll both be destroyed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got the bill here to pay yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...where Dr. Joseph Lagerman, Head of Nephrology, perhaps remembered from an earlier scene, has been waiting for Bock. He joins them en route to the elevators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara has continued walking. Bock starts to follow her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock turns back to Lagerman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara is disappearing into an elevator. Bock starts after her, then turns back to Lagerman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hurry down the corridor to the elevators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elevator doors open. A nurse and visitor get out. Bock and Lagerman go into...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herb, you asked me to find that dialysis nurse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What dialysis nurse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go pay the bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one who goofed on your patient, Drummond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, her name is Theresa Campanella, but you are not going to believe this, Herb. She died on the operating table in O. R. Three about an hour ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, she died on the operating table in O.R. Three?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean she was the one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the one. I just identified her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell's going on around here? Every time I try to find somebody in this hospital, they either died of a heart attack in Emergency or of anesthesia shock in an operating room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two or three people besides the elevator operator are there, as well as a patient on a stretcher and an orderly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator stops at the seventh floor. The doors open and Bock and Lagerman stroll into...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I just came from the O.R. They're trying to find a Dr. Schaefer. Don't you have a kid named Schaefer in your service?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scowls, mutters) I had a Schaefer. He died yesterday of an overdose of insulin. What do they want Schaefer for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Holding Room nurse says there was a Dr. Schaefer hanging around the Holding Room. It wouldn't have been your Schaefer anyway. The nurse says it was senior staff, a middle- aged man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no senior staff named Schaefer in this hospital.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told them that. I said, I don't know any senior staff around here named Schaefer. They've got detectives down there, everything. It's a whole big investigation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bock lumbers down the west corridor, turns into...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Mead, sedated and apparently zonked out cold, is being transferred from a stretcher back into bed by an O.R. orderly and nurse's aid. Bock rolls back the curtains around Drummond's bed revealing the comatose patient, his face sculptured against the white pillow, an I.V. tube in his right arm, a catheter projecting from under the sheet. Bock lowers the protective railing, leans in, takes the man's pulse on his neck, raises one closed eyelid, then the other. The pupils stare vacuously back at him; the eyelids drop closed as soon as they are released. In the background, the orderly and aid finish tucking in William Mead and exit, wheeling their creaking stretcher out. The room is shockingly silent. Bock goes to the window and frowns in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the patient Drummond, on Bock in the background at the window with his back to us. Suddenly, Drummond's eyes open. He lies rigid, his eyes staring dementedly into the air above him. Slowly, his left hand reaches out and carefully withdraws the catheter from his bladder, lays it on the white sheet beside him, and silently reaches over to withdraw the I.V. needle from his right arm. He lets the needle dangle, dripping onto the bed. Carefully, he twists out from under his sheet, swings his legs over the side of the bed and sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock at the window, pondering. With a swift lash of movement, the double tubes of a stethoscope are whipped over his head and tightened around his throat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mad as a hatter) I am the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: TWO SHOT of Bock being strangled, Drummond's face frozen in bland dementia behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drummond pauses in his strangling and, releasing the poor man altogether, turns to his daughter in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) For heaven's sake, Dad! What the hell's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to include all three -- Bock recuperating; Drummond staring madly; and Barbara infuriated with her father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drummond, abashed, stands there, a scolded schoolboy, a rawboned figure in a hospital shift, a stethoscope dangling from his right hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) We all thought you were at Death's Door! What're you doing out of bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bock) What happened? Did he say anything to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sufficiently recovered) As a matter of fact, he said, "I am the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca." And you'd better close the door, because if he's going to tell everyone who walks in here he's the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca, they'll put us all away. He's already killed two doctors and one nurse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the wrath of the lamb and the angel of the bottomless pit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean he killed two doctors and a nurse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, he's killed two doctors and a nurse! And he just tried to kill me! He has something against doctors. Somehow he got hold of a thousand units of insulin and put it in Dr. Schaefer's intravenous solution. And somehow he got Dr. Ives to die of a heart attack in the middle of the Emergency Room. And somehow he got a dialysis nurse named Campanella to die of anesthesia shock on an operating table! (opens the closet, points to the white doctor's uniform hanging there) He's been running around the hospital wearing Dr. Schaefer's uniform. Right now, they're looking all over the place for this mysterious Dr. Schaefer. I know this all sounds as grotesque to you as it does to me, but you can see for yourself your father is not the helpless comatose patient we thought he was. Don't look at me like I'm the one who's crazy. Ask your crazy father!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was merely an instrument of God. I killed no one. They all three died by their own hands, ritual victims of their own institutions, murdered by irony, an eye for an eye, biblical retribution. Schaefer was first, you see, because he killed God. God was admitted to this hospital last Monday under the name of Guernsey...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING. (FLASHBACK) A cheerless, gray sunlight fills the room as the fragile, white-haired and bearded old Guernsey (whose admittance to the hospital was the opening scene of the film) is being helped into the room by Nurse Felicia Chile. She solicitously helps the wispy old man off with his coat and jacket and hat which she puts in the armoire. With palsied fingers, the little old man unknots his stringy tie and unbuttons the collar, which is three sizes too large. In the other bed, Drummond's eyes slowly open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man is slipping out of his clothes to expose a thin little body in a torn nightshirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man sits back, wheezing a little. Nurse Chile smiles nicely at him and takes her leave. For a moment, Drummond lies rigidly on his bed, staring dully into the air and the old man sits with his hunched back to us. The room is silent except for his rheumy wheeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment, the old man rises and goes to the washbasin and, with some wheezing, spits into it. He shuffles back to bed. Dr. Schaefer comes into the room with a professional smile and the patient Guernsey's chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schaefer perches on the bed beside Guernsey and begins to take his history.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) I was instantly aware of a divine presence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) I was convinced this porcelain old man was, in fact, an Angel of the Lord...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) ...perhaps even Christ Himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) Our Savior was, it seems, suffering from emphysema.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) He was relentlessly subjected to the benefits of modern medicine. He was misdiagnosed, mismedicated, and put into shock by Dr. Schaefer; raced off to Intensive Care, where the resident compounded the blunder and induced a coma. I can tell you with authority that God is indeed dead. He died last Monday under the name of Guernsey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP of Drummond in deep shadow shows him sleeping.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) A few hours later, he appeared to me in a revelation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT, 7:00 P.M. The room is lit only by the yellow light from the half-opened bathroom door. Guernsey walks out of the shadows, hands raised. He shuffles to Drummond's bedside and looks down on him from his frail height.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drummond's eyes open and roll to the direction of the voice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Rise up, Drummond. You are dead, now you are restored.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Guernsey, dressed only in his hospital shift, is shuffling up and down the aisle of the room, hands clasped behind his back like a Mittel-European intellectual, head hunched forward -- a little old man with a white beard talking to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guernsey closes his eyes in religious ecstacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drummond starts to sob and slowly sits up in his bed, imbued with belief. He looks mutely up at the frail old man, who now raises his right hand and his face is transfigured into vast majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So saying, he reverts to the little old man he was, wheezing a bit, and with some effort, climbs back on his bed and lies there, eyes closed. His thin, high nose projects from the whiteness of his face. He sighs the rattling last sigh of life and dies. CAMERA DOLLIES slowly to CLOSE-UP of Drummond lying motionless on his bed. His eyes are wide, glinting in the shadows, a man imbued. His cheeks are wet with tears of exaltation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Those who killed you and those who killed me will die in our place. You are the Paraclete of Caborca, the wrath of the lamb. The angel of the bottomless pit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In this fashion has it been revealed to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thunders out) The age is closed! The end is at hand! The seal is broken!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) Well! Not quite the burning bush perhaps but prodigal enough for me. I was to avenge the death of God and my own brutalization. I was to kill Doctors Schaefer, Ives and Welbeck and the dialysis nurse Miss Campanella, whose negligence caused my coma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Drummond. He raises his left hand, flexing his fingers. Then he moves his other arm, his head, his shoulders. Obviously, he is regaining his faculties.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) I awaited a further sign from God, which was given to me later that evening. Dr. Schaefer, it seems, had arranged an assignation with a girl from the hematology lab named Sheila.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Drummond to the now empty other bed. All the lights are on. PAN on Nurse Penny Canduso and an orderly wheeling away the wrapped body of Guernsey. Intern Schaefer, at the door, considers the empty bed with interest. Moving to the bedtable, he picks up the receiver of the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Hey Sheila, this is Howard, Sheila. Hey listen, I got us a bed for tonight. A real, honest-to-god bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT REPRISE the scene originally played UNDER CREDITS where Dr. Schaefer and his girlfriend Sheila sneak into the room and undress. Giggles and shushings, gooses and fondles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the replay, however, an additional segment is added. At one point, the girl, hanging her dress in the armoire, turns and holds something up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They head for the unoccupied bed. CLOSE-UP on Drummond's profile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, I sure hope nobody walks in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this in your pocket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's my insulin. Put it back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you take insulin for? Diabetes? I didn't know you were a diabetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't contagious, don't worry about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dark, hushed. Schaefer's girl is leaving; she tiptoes to the door, peeks out. Apparently, the coast is clear. She quickly slips out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Drummond on his chair. Barbara perched on one side of her father's bed, Bock on the other. William Mead sleeps on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And you put Schaefer's insulin into the I.V. jar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. And then a second nurse came and plugged the I.V. jar into Schaefer. God clearly intended a measure of irony here. The hospital was to do all the killing for me. All I need do was arrange for the doctors to become patients in their own hospital. Accordingly, the next morning, I set out for Dr. Ives. I put on Dr. Schaefer's uniform, pinched some digoxine from the pharmacy and a sandbag from a utility cart, and found my way to Dr. Ives' laboratory. I coshed him with the sandbag, gave him a massive shot of the digoxine. This, you see, brought on an instant condition of cardiac arrhythmia. When he came to, I brought him down to the Emergency Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The usual E.R. crush and motion goes on in the background. Drummond escorts an obviously ill Dr. Ives to the Admitting Room. Drummond's voice under the narration explains matters to Miss Aronovici at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go into the...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is Dr. Ives. He's in the Nephrology Lab. I was in there a little while ago, and he was suddenly taken ill, and I thought I'd better get him over here right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) He had at that time perhaps an hour to live. Prompt treatment would have saved his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ives, seated on a table in evident distress, breathes heavily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An attendant takes his pulse, pressure and respiration. Ives collapses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) As a staff doctor, he was seen without preliminaries...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) His vital signs were taken, an electrocardiogram...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SLOWLY across the Emergency Room to catch its state of contained febrility. Every curtained treatment room is occupied, including the storage room in the back. The triage nurse and a second nurse behind the desk are busy on the phones. The triage nurse takes the history of the first in a line of five people seeking admission even as she answers her phone. We watch Miss Aronovici and the other nurse and Dr. Spezio and his two interns, the two attendants -- all busy with one patient or another.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) ...which revealed occasional ventricular premature contractions. An intern took his history...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Drummond, white-uniformed, standing in the back against the filing cabinets and linens, watching the the new patients trickle and crowd in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the Admitting Desk, a MAN in his forties is being signed in by a uniformed cop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) ...and then he was promptly...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) ...simply... forgotten to death. Simply mislaid...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at the pageant of pain.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice-off) ...mislaid among the broken wrists, the chest pains, scalp lacerations, the man whose fingers were crushed in a taxi door, the infant with the skin rash, the child swiped by a car, the old lady mugged in the subway, the derelict beaten by sailors, the teenage suicide, the paranoids, drunks, asthmatics, the rapes, the septic abortions, the overdosed addicts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking to the street doors as two ambulance attendants, bearing a seventeen-year-old black girl on a stretcher, burst in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hurry into the Admitting Room past a nurse and into the...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Not breathing! Not breathing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...which is already galvanized into action. Miss Aronovici is at the girl's pulse even as she is being transferred to the bed that has just been cleared of Mr. Mitgang and his concussion case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On screen we continue watching the scene of the overdose case treatment, as the live-action sound in the room fades behind Drummond's tale.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (instructing attendant with Mitgang) Better put him in the Holding Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with the seventeen- year-old girl) She's taking a little pulse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . SPEZIO (to triage nurse) Get an anesthesiologist, one-five- one-five...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) ...the fractures, infarcts, hemorrhages, concussions, boils, abrasions, the colonic cancers, the cardiac arrests -- the whole wounded madhouse of our times...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Drummond staring at this ceaseless panorama of pain, tears streaking down his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drummond turns to the voice. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the man who had been brought into the E.R. by a uniformed cop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) I wonder if I could have a minute of your time, Doctor...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's an honor and a privilege, Doctor. I've been here ten minutes, I can't seem to get anybody to help me. I'm suffering from some sort of amnesia. I can't remember my name. As a matter of fact, it's pretty screwy. I got mugged. Two hours ago, walking out of a coffee shop on Fifty- Seventh Street and Second Avenue, eight o'clock in the morning, broad daylight, I got mugged. A sixteen- year-old girl walks up to me, shows me a knife about a yard long and says, "Give me your wallet." I thought she was kidding. I mean there's hundreds of people walking right by. Well, she wasn't kidding. "Listen," I said, "all I got's about twenty bucks." So she takes the wallet anyway. So I said, "How about leaving me my identification?" I mean, I had my driver's license, my Diner's Club, my credit cards. But she took them all, the whole damn wallet, credit cards, everything. So I stopped some guy, I said, "Hey, you see that girl there, walking away?" He says, "Yeah." I said, "She just stole my wallet, credit cards and everything." He says, "Well, that's what they want, the credit cards." So I started looking for a cop. I mean, go find a cop, right? Well, I finally find a cop. The girl's halfway to South America by now, probably bought the ticket with my credit cards. So the cop says, "What's your name?" And you want to know something? I couldn't think of my name. The girl took all my identification, you know what I mean? She took all my credit cards. So I said, "You know this is screwy. I can't think of my name." So he took me to the station house. The sergeant says, "What's your name?" I said, "I don't know! She took all my credit cards!" So they took me down here. So what do you think, Doctor? I'm nuts, right? I finally flipped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SLOWLY to Drummond who stares at the Nameless Man. In BACKGROUND the door opens and Mrs. Cushing, the lady from accounting, enters. She calls out in her annoying voice from a chart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . CUSHING Who's number 7-6-8-0-2-S? Is there anybody here who is that number?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) In this way was it revealed to me the manner of Nurse Campanella's death. She was to die of the great American plague -- vestigial identity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Drummond in his hospital shift, gaunt and mad as a prophet, sits rigidly on his chair. Barbara perches on her father's bed. Bock wanders disorientedly about the room, staring incredulously first at Barbara and then at her father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock holds Drummond's coat and hat and crosses to take his arm. He finds the entranced Drummond as rigid as a statue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both hurry out of the room. Drummond remains enmarbled in his trance. CAMERA SUDDENLY MOVES DOWN to William Mead, whose eyes now open; he has heard it all. In background, Drummond, suddenly released from his catatonic trance, heads for the armoire and extracts the white trousers of Dr. Schaefer's uniform. He puts them on, tucking in the tails of his hospital shift. He notices William Mead staring at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Mead just stares at Drummond.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So last night, I coshed Miss Campanella with a sandbag, sedated her with thorazine, shaved her, prepped her, and parked her in a corridor of the X-Ray Department for five hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why X-Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, at X-Ray, a sedated body lying around unattended for five hours wouldn't seem unusual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her operation -- that is to say, Mrs. Mangafranni's operation -- was not scheduled until nine-thirty. So at nine-fifteen this morning, I rang for my nurse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You rang for your nurse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To insure one full hour of uninterrupted privacy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got up, wheeled Miss Campanella off to the operating rooms, replaced her bed with Mrs. Mangafranni's, exchanged charts and identity bracelets. She died officially of anesthesia shock. But, in point of fact, she died because she was wearing another woman's identity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bock) God, what do we do now? Let me take him back to Mexico. It's a simple world there. If you turn him in, they'll just cage him in the Rockland State Hospital for the Criminally Insane. Let me take him back, Herb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you kidding? We'll both take him. I'm going with you! Get him dressed. We're getting out of here before the police put us all in Rockland State.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't finished my work here. I have this Welbeck to dispose of. I am the angel of the bottomless pit and the wrath of the lamb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh dear, he's having another revelation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, that ambulance must be here by now. You go down and get them. I'll give him a shot of something to knock him out. We'll take him to the airport in the ambulance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're hallucinating again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bock and Barbara come hurrying around the corner from the west corridor. Barbara heads for the elevators. Bock heads for the Nurses' Station. The Eighth Floor is going about its normal 1:15 P.M. activity. Mrs. Donovan is at her desk on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nurse's aid, a bathrobed patient and two of his visitors stroll by. It's the end of the lunch hour, when the kitchen workers bring used trays back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock moves past Mrs. Donovan and into the pharmacy where we see him scouring the shelves for thorazine and a syringe. An elevator arrives, disgorging Milton Mead and his resident assistant, Thomas Hitchcock and, of all people, Dr. Richard Welbeck himself. Barbara and Dr. Biegelman go into the elevator. The doors close. Milton Mead and Hitchcock head for the west corridor. Welbeck, in his natty double-breasted suit and carrying his cashmere coat, heads straight for the Nurses' Station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock immediately emerges from the pharmacy holding a bottle of thorazine and a wrapped hypodermic syringe. He scowls at Welbeck, who scowls back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to pass Mrs. Donovan and would continue, but Welbeck lays a restraining hand on his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welbeck's pocket-beeper BEEPS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bock turns and heads back for...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EIGHTH FLOOR, NURSES' STATION AND LOBBY AREA

dialogue.raw_text: . DONOVAN ...Edwards never showed up. I'm short- staffed as hell. It's just me and Felicia. It's like Sunday. Nobody's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BIEGELMAN I'll be at lunch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DONOVAN Yeah, you gotta send me somebody... Oh yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll be in Eight-O-Six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DONOVAN (chuckles into phone) ...then what did she say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mrs. Donovan) I'm Dr. Welbeck. I have a patient on this floor named Drummond, and I'd like to see his chart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DONOVAN I'll call you back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Dr. Bock. Can I have a few minutes of your time, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Gilley tells me you're the one who initiated these proceedings against me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm busy, Welbeck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to know what you have against me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You turned up half-stoned for a simple nephrectomy eight days ago, botched it, put the patient into failure and damn near killed him. Then, pausing only to send in your bill, you flew off on the wings of man to an island of sun in Montego Bay. This is the third time in two years we've had to patch up your patients; the other two died. You're greedy, unfeeling, inept, indifferent, self-inflating and unconscionably profitable. Aside from that, I have nothing against you. I'm sure you play a hell of a game of golf. What else do you want to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me for a moment, Doctor. (he reaches over the nurses' desk for a phone) This is Dr. Welbeck. Were you paging me? (regarding Bock with cold scorn) How much do you make a year, Bock? For a guy who makes a lousy forty, fifty grand... (on phone) Hello, Arthur, I understand you've been trying to reach me all morning...

Bock moves quickly to the prostrate Welbeck, feels his throat for the carotid pulse, pulls out his stethoscope, rips Welbeck's shirt open, and listens for heartsounds. He picks up the dangling telephone receiver, gets a dial tone.

He begins intensive heart massage. Barbara gets down on her knees, opens Welbeck's mouth and commences mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. In the background, the P.A. system blandly echoes: P.A. SYSTEM (off-screen) C.A.C. Holly Eight. Please clear all corridors. Mrs. Donovan and aides move C.A.C. into the room, immediately followed by Intern Chandler rushing past them.

direction.raw_text: William Mead, of course, is still huddled under his sheet. He peers out from under his covers in wide-eyed disbelief and ducks under again. Bock massages Welbeck's heart. Barbara continues mouth-to-mouth. Nurse Felicia Chile hurries in, pushing the emergency cart before her.

People crowd in a solid block in the doorway to the coffee shop to see what's going on. From the long tunnels of corridors, nurses, doctors, administrative personnel pause in their chores and errands and missions to watch the tide of events in the lobby.

direction.raw_text: The exit door is wrenched open, and Bock comes hurtling into the carpeted executive corridor toward the lobby, and at that moment the troop of militants come rumbling in from the other end. Every door of the corridor fills with secretaries and administrators unsure of what's happening. Then, Sundstrom elbows his way through the clutch of secretaries in his doorway and comes into the corridor. He regards the militants moving down the corridor toward him.

direction.raw_text: The mass engulfs Sundstrom, moving back out into the lobby with him, pushing him, shoving him, humiliating him.

direction.raw_text: . DAY The Reverend Drummond stands, a solitary human island, among the shrill ROAR of the city. The protesters protest endlessly, CHANTING, SHOUTING. Absolutely no one pays any attention to the gaunt, doctor-clad sixty-year-old man standing on an island. Except, of course, for Bock, who must pause to wait for a red light. Bock hustles through the traffic to where Drummond stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ambulance pulls up and Barbara gets out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The light turns green. The traffic starts flowing around them, disjoined by the ambulance blocking one lane on each side of the dividing island. An ambulance attendant has opened the back doors to get Drummond in. Barbara hurries toward the front, climbs in, holds the door open for Bock. He stands a few paces back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, and the ambulance pulls away. Bock goes back to the sidewalk where he meets Sundstrom, now wearing his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They make their way back toward...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, for the age is closed, the season of the seventh seal is at hand! The age is closed! The season of the seventh se...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Welbeck is dead. They thought he was you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know. We must arrange to have his body shipped to my Apache village where we will bury him with full tribal rites. In a day or two, somebody'll ask, "Whatever happened to Dr. Welbeck?" And it will be assumed he absconded to Brazil to join his partner, the eminent orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Noel Hogan. Welbeck, too, was mislaid, overlooked, forgotten to death, you see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking her father around to the back) We have to hurry, Dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going. (he moves to the ambulance, closes the door) The hospital's coming apart. I can't walk out on it when it's coming apart. Somebody has to be responsible, Barbara. Everybody's hitting the road, running to the hills, running away. Somebody's got to be responsible. (across Barbara to the driver) Kennedy Airport. You've got a two- thirty flight to make.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You going back in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two physicians trudge across the U-drive.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (matter-of-factly) It's like pissing in the wind, right, Herb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue
